title: My first reaction to Pyke...
body:
I wish riot would make a champ that's actually scary.  

I mean if you are going to do horror, you should go for something actually disturbing or horrifying.  You should go for something that comments on humanity and makes people think.  Maybe allegorical for real life events.  Take Godzilla.  When it was released, the fire bombing of Tokyo and two cities getting nuked by an unstoppable war machine Japan had provoked was fresh on everyone's mind.  A giant monster that Japan was unable to defend against made sense for the time.  Poe's writing worked because it dealt with madness most of all.  Lovecraft worked in the form of hint unreliably after you've built a base of madness.  

Pyke seems like a satire aimed at 12 year olds.  "I got fed to the fishies and now I'm back for revenge, garr!"

On that note, he looks rather human for a walking pile of fish shit.  I mean you'd think after the Last Jedi debacle, your hype team would know what Checkov's Gun is by now.  If you are going to hint that he was eaten by a giant fish, then I'm expecting something that would look digested, or at least thoroughly chewed up and missing a chunk of his body and not a generic bloated corpse that drowned.

Now if you want to go with drowned corpse coming back for revenge, then you needed to have shown that he died by drowning or freezing to death in the water.  Get rid of the fish entirely.  Maybe put a few obvious holes in his story, just enough to make him seem unreliable.  Better yet, make him have gone crazy and then he jumped off the ship.  Something terrible happened on the boat in the middle of the ocean and he tried to escape the only way his panicked mind would allow and now he's back to warn others about whatever it was.

Checkov's Gun is bad to be used universally. It's just a rule that occasionally works, mostly only in situations in which pacing and time or space restraint is of utter most importance, but otherwise it's not strictly needed to be followed to create a good narrative.

For those who don't know, Checkov's Gun is a rule that goes as follows:

> Remove everything that has no relevance to the story. If you say in the first chapter that there is a rifle hanging on the wall, in the second or third chapter it absolutely must go off. If it's not going to be fired, it shouldn't be hanging there

It's a good rule of thumb to look to to remind the writer to at least do some proper fat-cutting of stories and designs to avoid bloating, but there is otherwise no need to specifically tie everything directly to the narrative, or at least not all the time. For instance, a short story would benefit the most from this rule, whereas any things like the storyboard for an exploration RPG wouldn't mind lots of detours.

To some extent we can apply to this Pyke guy. Just because there was a sea creature of sort in his teaser (Nagakabouros?), doesn't mean he has to be wrapped entirely around it.

I don't know what you're on about because Pyke's visual design looks like it's going to be one of League's scariest yet.

Personally if I'm thinking Lovecraft, I'm excited for the potential reworks of {{champion:9}} and {{champion:31}} more than anything.

They can't make his character design too graphic though,since it would raise the age rating of the game in several countries(they already had to censor vladimirs blood in some regions,so making him look half-digested would definitely not work).

Also from what we know,he might actually comment on a rather common problem in todays society,the bystander-syndrome,where people don't take action to help someone in need.

Heck this actually reminds me of the case where a bunch of teens filmed a drowning man and made fun of him instead of helping him,which happened in july 2017,the time where Pyke was likely in the early iteration-phases.

What Last Jedi debacle?
People wanted all their fan theories to be answered (Rey is a Kenobi or Skywalker, Snoke was some Sith lord from the prequels, etc.)

I think a bigger issue is that JJ actually written up a guide for the next two films while working on TFA, the third director signed on assuming that was what was going to happen, but rian johnson threw everything out the window to make the most nihilistic movie I can remember seeing.  See, the marvel movies work because there was a clear goal in mind for all of them and I think the star wars ones are failing because it's basically each director doing his own thing while disney demands they print more money faster.

So while it was fine if the theories didn't come true, what happened is the movie didn't resolve them satisfyingly.  I can't talk much about avengers: infinity war for another day, but I will say I and a lot of others felt satisfied with how things resolved.  TLJ lacks a cohesive message and everything about it is unsatisfying.  I don't even know if the movie even had a point or a reason for existing at this point because it sabotages its own messages at the end.  

Part of me actually wonders if the ending was a reshoot that disney forced because it didn't like the proper ending that rian johnson had come up with that actually fit the story he was telling.

Infinity War is imo garbage because it set out with a circular writing with time and future predicting shenanigans; and instead of actually doing some kind of effort to progress the story organically to reach the destination, it just banks entirely on that and have all the characters drop their IQ by 200 to do and make the most stupid decisions ever, and having "the big ending" for cheap shock value that means absolutely nothing because you KNOW it will be lifted due to the fact it does it so way too incredibly extreme to be true and permanent for the later plots.

Infinity War's story is completely dumb and certainly didn't try at all whatsoever, and the extreme deus ex machina road-paving isn't even the worst sin it has committed, but the fact to support this awful arch-plot they made everybody so incredibly dumb (both the heroes and the villains; and having them fight like it's fucking 900 AD even though they're fucking superheros with superpowers with supertechnology), that they castrated Hulk just to pad the story because otherwise the story could've actually ended half way through (why would Hulk be afraid? Being dicked on should make him ANGRY and STRONGER), and worst of all of this, they have the nerve to use time bullshit as an self-excusing justification for their absolutely awful writing. "It's the only way... so every dumb shit we do is actually the only way to lead to victory, and all my mindblowingly brain drain writing is actually the best" You fucking wot?

.........

I also don't really get the hate for TLJ. Sure Rose is a COMPLETELY UNNECESSARY character who only exists to pad the story in rather uncomfortable ways; I mean, she's both a PETA advert, a plot padding machine with worse display of character than Jar Jar, and a complete nuisance that exists solely to annoy and go against everything Finn says and does, why are we expected to like her? Sure Snoke was a complete let down, hilarious memes even. Sure the casino bit of the movie almost shouldn't exist, or at least could be cut by half and would make no difference. Sure the purple hair chick 'fake suspense' section could literally never happen if she just told the others the fucking plan she had, instead of acting like a douche and refuses to say anything. 

But all of this are imo nowhere as bad as TFA has collectively represented. Because not only TFA is a shallow rehash of ANH, it makes absolutely no sense (the setting, the plot points, you name it) while bending established dynamics of the title whenever they please, and creating this gigantic rambo power fantasy where the only take-away is that "Rey is amazing, she literally does everything in the story and everybody else is kind of just there". That's far more insulting than TLJ, because at least The Force, the good o' Force vs Dark Side is actually a thing now in TLJ unlike TFA, and story actually progresses and pushes the narratives forward into the next big stage, AND it ended semi-conclusively with the stuff presented in the movie itself tying up for the most part unlike TFA which just dumped a bunch of utterly ridiculous shit and never bothered to go back to them and just ended the movie in one of the worst cliffhanger ever. 

I find JJ's "mystery box" approach (I'm not putting words in his mouth. That's his words) far more insulting than R.Johnson's whatever philosophy, because R.ohnson actually tells a story meanwhile JJ is entirely content with just doing his lootbox shit with 1 box in another box like a fake carrot on a stick. JJ doesn't even seem to attempt to tell a story but rather he's more about just holding baits to lead the audience around in circles (and neither leading them absolutely nowhere or the worst payoffs), it by all accounts of nature make his TFA far worse than TLJ imho.

I hope the next champion they finally make something interesting again. The last time I actually was impressed at a new champion was Tahm Kench and I don't remember when he was released but it had to be at least a few years ago. All of these recent releases have just been so boring. 

The lore and idea behind most of the champions is unique but the kit on them just never lives up to my expectations. I expected something grand with Ivern, but was so massively disappointed upon his release. I was hoping for some awesome champion who spawns huge forests with his attacks and instead get this guy who instantly makes camps vanish and throws bushes on the ground. It's as though Riot has no creativity whatsoever.

When I look at this guy in the teaser, I can't help but think that he's going to be some overpowered Illaoi and Kayn hybrid with nothing interesting at all except for the fact that he's strong as hell (due to needing to be a Support with kill potential). He reminds me mostly of Darius and god knows, I remember Darius at release like it was yesterday. The last thing this game needs is another repeat of the nightmare that was Darius from those days...
